newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's Jospin wants shift EU to jobs, growth.
newsitem.headline: France's Jospin wants shift EU to jobs, growth.

text.p: Socialist leader Lionel Jospin, pledging policies based on "respect" if the left won France's close parliamentary election, said on Friday he would seek to re-orient the European Union towards jobs and growth.

Buoyed by opinion polls showing the left in striking range of an upset victory in the May 25-June 1 vote, Jospin said France needed to restore confidence in its rulers after a string of broken promises and errors by right and left.
"To change, France must find confidence in itself," the white-haired former education minister, 59, wrote in an article appearing in French newspapers on Friday.
"It will only do so by finding confidence in its leaders. It's a question of respect...the foundation of this future we want to build."

Jospin's article, following a column by President Jacques Chirac on Wednesday criticising the left and seeking to persuade voters to re-elect his centre-right coalition, said one pillar of Socialist policy would be "respect for Europe."

"We want a Europe without undoing France. We do not want Europe to dissolve into globalisation," Jospin said, reaffirming that the Socialists wanted a single European currency but only on certain conditions.

"We want to re-orient European policy towards growth and jobs," he said, urging faith in a "world which does not have to be this jungle we are promised by the self-interested fatalists of unrestricted liberalism and finance."

French voters, weary of political sleaze and rising unemployment, dumped the Socialists in 1993 in the last National Assembly elections. But both factors now threaten Prime Minister Alain Juppe's centre-right coalition.
"We have know how to draw the lessons of the 10 years during which we were in government. I take responsibility, and the Socialist party with me, for the past errors," Jospin said.

Polls show many voters are disillusioned with politicians and believe neither the Socialists nor Juppe's coalition have answers to their main concern -- record unemployment of 12.8 percent of the workforce.
Jospin, who has reputation of being short on charisma but long on honesty, was defeated by Chirac in the 1995 presidential election.
He said his policies would be based on "respect for truth", "respect for the individual", "respect for what binds us", "respect for Europe" and "respect for democracy".
He described Chirac's criticisms of the left's platform and record as "negative, partisan and unfair" but he otherwise steered clear of personal barbs.
An Ipsos opinion poll for the weekly Le Point magazine projected that the ruling coalition would win 290 seats in the 577-member National Assembly, just one more than would be needed for a majority.
It forecast that the Socialists and their allies would get 264 seats, the Communists 22 and the far-right National Front one.
It was the narrowest lead for Juppe's coalition since Chirac, elected to a seven-year term ending in 2002, gambled his presidency by calling the early election.

Chirac called the vote saying that the government needed a new impetus to combat unemployment and enter a single European currency from a position of strength. But he risks becoming a lame duck for the next five years if the left wins.
